result.description: Popular for seasoning coffee, peppermint syrup is an okay companion to have around the bar, too. Especially as substitute for peppermint schnapps.
result.name: Peppermint Syrup

result.description: Yellow/orange rose petals, can me used to garnish drinks and its surrounding for a more dramatic effect. If used in drinks make sure the petals is not poisonous.
result.name: Petals (edible)

result.description: A bitter with a scent of florals might sound contradictory but that is the complementary tastes of Peychaud bitters. Bitters are a great ingredient in a bar adding that extra level of taste complexity to your drinks.
result.name: Peychaud's bitters

result.description: Pickled cherries, also known as maraschino berries, are perhaps the most classic of garnishes. Often comes with a somewhat artificial aftertaste, so rinse off before putting it in your cocktail.
result.name: Pickled Cherry

result.description: English, gin-based liqueur tasting of fruit and herbs. The legend holds that only six persons know the recipe.
result.name: Pimms Cup No 1

result.description:
The pineapple is also known as ananas, which in Tupi means "excellent". As excellent as fresh pineapple is, it's sort of hard to peel. Use a sharp knife! (Trivia 1: The surface of all pineapples are based on Fibonacci numbers. Trivia 2: Pineapples can weigh up to nine pounds!)

The leaves of the pineapple make nice, yet inedible, garnish.
result.name: Pineapple

result.description: A very useful mixer, often sold in small cans – very convenient, as pineapple juice often are consumed in small amounts. Tend to foam when shaken.
result.name: Pineapple Juice

result.description: A clear liqueur tasting of… pineapple. Can be replaced with a small amount of rum and some pineapple juice.
result.name: Pineapple Liqueur

result.description: A rum-based liqueur with pineapple flavor.
result.name: Pineapple Rum

result.description: Available bottled in most supermarkets but oh so easy to make fresh at home. Just boil water and sugar together, add pineapples, and leave to cool. Remove :the pineapple pieces and enjoy your fresh home-made pineapple syrup!
result.name: Pineapple syrup

result.description: The grapefruit equivalent of blood orange is pink grapefruit, which gives excellent juice. Can be replaced with regular grapefruit juice, although the color is more boring.
result.name: Pink Grapefruit Juice

result.description:
Lemonade is a perfect  summer refresher and pink lemonade is even more fun. To make it pink in the old days they used to make it with sumac berries but now-days the use grenadine, cranberry, pomegranate or
strawberry juice to color the lemonade.
result.name: Pink Lemonade Concentrate (frozen)

result.description: Small, bright-red spherical drupe with a single seed, with a sweet and mild taste, also very aromatic. May be used crushed and sprinkled on meat, in sauces, desserts or mixed in pepper blends. Oh, and in drinks of course.
result.name: Pink Peppers

result.description: An extremely sweet, very green liqueur, tasting of fruits and herbs. (Might be tricky to find in the US, also hard to substitute).
result.name: Pisang Ambon

result.description: A South-American kind of brandy, made from grapes. The knowledge around and popularity of pisco has increased majorly over the last years. And we don't mind: Pisco Sour is a modern classic.
result.name: Pisco

result.description: A member of the cashew family, the pistachio is the edible pale green seed of a small Asian tree. Nutty and sweet, it gives ice-cream a unique flavor – try it!
result.name: Pistachio ice cream

result.description: The pistachio kernels are eaten whole, either fresh or roasted and salted, and are also used in ice cream and confections such as baklava. Pistachios are rare as drink garnish, but its colorful appearance might help it to find its place in the bar more than just as a snack.
result.name: Pistachio Nut

result.description: The fruit behind the plum brandy slivovitz, works as a garnish, too with its sweet and juicy taste. It can be eaten fresh and is exelent to muddle.
result.name: Plum

result.description: Brandy comes in many costumes, and plum makes a good foundation for brandy. Plum brandy is often sold under the name of slivovitz, but also known as mirabelle or pflümliwasser.
result.name: Plum Brandy

result.description: The national flower of China has a fruit: plum. It has very good digestion effects, and the juice tastes good – but can be dispensed with in the bar.
result.name: Plum Juice

result.description: Damson Gin obtains its rich colour from the fruit, in the same way as Sloe Gin. It is a full bodied liqueur which is naturally sweeter than Sloe Gin. It is lighter on the palate, but still has a full aroma on the nose that is soft yet unmistakably full of the flavour of plums.
result.name: Plymouth Damson Gin Liqueur

result.description: Plymouth's Fruit Cup is at the perfect strength of 30% abv. giving it a fuller flavour. At its heart is our Plymouth Gin, blended with luxurious fruit liqueurs, vermouths, aromatic bitters, and pure citrus fruit extracts. The taste reveals a burst of tangerine and lime with aromatic fresh blossom.
result.name: Plymouth Fruit Cup

result.description: Sloe Gin has a rich red colour, which is the result of steeping the finest sloe berries in high strength Plymouth Gin and soft Dartmoor water. The result is a smooth liqueur taste with a beautiful balance between sweet and bitter fruit flavours, and a hint of almonds from the stone of the fruit.
result.name: Plymouth Sloe Gin

result.description: The next big thing in drinks!? Looking a bit like cranberry juice, tasting better and more original.
result.name: Pomegranate Juice

result.description: Pomegranate Seeds is versatile.  It gives great colour and taste to any drink and makes for beautiful garnish.
result.name: Pomegranate Seed

result.description: Portuguese, strong wine (around 40 proof/20%), made around the Oporto river. There is red and white port, both variations are well suited for aging (at home). Not very common in drinks, more usual as dessert wine.
result.name: Port, Red

result.description: Portuguese, strong wine (around 40 proof/20%), made around the Oporto river. There is red and white port, both variations are well suited for aging (at home). Not very common in drinks, more usual as dessert wine.
result.name: Port, White

result.description: Actually a grape species, grown in Italy, prosecco has named a sparkling wine from the region.
result.name: Prosecco

result.description: Despite its possibly negative connotations, prunes are dried plums. Brandy made from prunes taste a bit like raisins and plums, but has more kick (than raisins and plums).
result.name: Prune Eau de Vie

result.description: A pumpkin is a squash fruit that varies greatly in form, but is generally oblong. Although the pumpkin is classified as a fruit, it is widely regarded as a vegetable yet more common in the kitchen than in the bar. It has to be peeled and cooked before using.
result.name: Pumpkin Smash

result.description: Around Christmas every year, raisin consumption in Sweden increases by thousands of per cent, as its used as a garnish in the traditional, warm Glögg drink. There are other uses for the raisin in the bar as well – but is sure not indispensable.
result.name: Raisin

result.description: If to be really picky, it’s not really a berry but a drupe – but whatever; it goes with nearly anything! Try it with vanilla, for instance. Raspberry is a winner, no matter if muddled, in the mixer or just on top of the drink as a garnish.
result.name: Raspberry

result.description: A beautiful combination of garnishes for cocktails is raspberry and blackberry on a cocktail stick.
result.name: Raspberry/Blackberry

result.description: A sweet spread made from raspberries and sugar boiled to thick consistency. Available in most food stores.
result.name: Raspberry Jam

result.description: Juice made from raspberries – what is there not to love? Not very common in the bar though, and it can be substituted with raspberry syrup or -cordial.
result.name: Raspberry Juice

result.description: Often French, often red and intensely tasting of raspberries, and other intriguing spices. A good raspberry liqueur should probably be mandatory in all modern bars.
result.name: Raspberry Liqueur

result.description: Available in some supermarkets, but far from impossible to make at home by running raspberries, sugar and a splash or two of lemon juice.
result.name: Raspberry Puree

result.description: Raspberry flavored liqueur based on rum.
result.name: Raspberry Rum

result.description: A soft drink tasting of raspberries that can be bought at most supermarkets. Can possibly be replaced with raspberry cordial and lemon-lime soda.
result.name: Raspberry Soda

result.description: This infused syrup is easy to create by yourself. Just heat equal amounts of sugar and water to a bowl, add a pile of raspberries and let all ingredients simmer in a pan for 15 minutes, cool off and sieve into a bottle.
result.name: Raspberry Syrup

result.description: This member of the gooseberry family is a little sourer than the blackcurrant. Both are underestimated garnishes.
result.name: Red Currant

result.description: Instead of using grenadine, which is very sweet, one can use red food coloring – which isn't.
result.name: Red Food Coloring

result.description: Vermouth: A fortified wine, tasting of herbs and spices. Red vermouth: A sweet, bitter mixer. Several manufacturers make red vermouth. A must if you are to make Manhattans.
result.name: Red Vermouth

result.description: The difference between white and red wine is the color of the grape, and the red is made from blue grapes. As a mixer, red wine occur mostly in punches and such. It's good to keep a bottle in the bar (but beware of keeping open bottles too long – you'll have vinegar.)
result.name: Red Wine

result.description: Margarita = cocktail made of tequila, triple sec, and lime juice. Regular Margarita Mix is for the lazy: just add it to tequila and you're good to go. (Duh: making the drink from scratch is to prefer.)
result.name: Regular Margarita Mix

result.description: Far away from the popular image of tequila as a shot in between lemon and salt Reposado Tequila is a great base for your cocktails if you are striving for that fiery tequila spice and a rounder lingering taste.
result.name: Reposado Tequila

result.description: Rhubarb liqueur
result.name: Rhubarb liqueur

result.description: Rosemary is known as the herb of friendship, and what is better than a toast to true friendship?
result.name: Rosemary

result.description: Originally, and still used as, a beauty product for the skin. There are types of rosewater, however, that are not for ingestion. Buy yours in a health food store.
result.name: Rosewater

result.description: Rose wine can be made either by simply mixing red and white wine, or be made of blue (red) grapes that are removed from the process before leaving too much color.
result.name: Rose Wine

result.description: Ruby grapefruit is the only patented fruit we know of – nevertheless it makes a beautiful juice and a very good mixer. Can be replaced with regular grapefruit juice.
result.name: Ruby Grapefruit Juice

result.description: A rum-based liqueur with banana flavor.
result.name: Rum Banana Flavored

result.description: Should there be rum flavored with the state fruit of Utah, US? Off course; many drinks combine cherry liqueur and rum – and here's a combination. Enjoy.
result.name: Rum Cherry Flavored

result.description: There has been production of rum in Haiti since the French days. Rums from here are often highly respected, and can be enjoyed both in drinks and straight in a sniffer glass.
result.name: Rum of Haitian Type

result.description: Super-sweet fluid made by bees. Since it has a certain taste, it's not totally substitutional with simple syrup.
result.name: Runny Honey

result.description: Rye whiskey, often just called rye, is made in Canada (and then spelt whisky) and in the US. By law, it has to be made of rye. There are many famous producers of rye – in drinks it might be of less importance of which one you pick.
result.name: Rye Whiskey

result.description: The most expensive spice in the world is, maybe because of the price, not a regular element in the bar.
result.name: Saffron

result.description: Simple syrup is one of the most usable mixers in the bar, but it's quite cheap: Just heat equal parts of water and sugar until dissolved. Now, to make saffron simple syrup, or saffron simple syrup which is more expensive and has a certain sting to it: add saffron to taste when you make it. (And remember: Cool the syrup down before using it in the cocktail.)
result.name: Saffron Sugar Syrup

result.description: In Japanese, sake simply means "alcoholic beverage". It is made from rice and has been produced for at least some 1 600 years.
result.name: Sake

result.description: An ingredient so basic that it needs no further introduction. Used to pop the flavour of other ingredients or for rimming the glass.
result.name: Salt

result.description: Italian liqueur with taste of elderflower and anise. When served neat, three coffee beans are often put in the glass (for good luck.)
result.name: Sambuca

result.description: A white, sweet, wine from France. Considered the finest dessert wine in the world and has been called "the milk of gourmets."
result.name: Sauterne

result.description: There are four different types of whisky in Scotland: single malt, blended, vatted and single grain. The first is probably the best known, and much appreciated among experts or when drunk neat.
result.name: Scotch Whisky

result.description: Though originally from Spain, sherry now is made all over the world. It's a fortified wine, but normally dry. Good with spicy delicacies, and not as odd in drink recipes as one may think.
result.name: Sherry

result.description: This is something every bar must have! Make it at home by heating equal parts of sugar and water until sugar is completely dissolved. Let cool off, and pour to bottles or some other vessel that is easy to use.
result.name: Simple Syrup

result.description: Yellowish plum brandy made in Balkan of Eastern Europe – the best slivovitz is traditionally reckoned to come from Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Serbia, but slivovitz is also manufactured in the US. (Other examples of plum brandies are mirabelle and pflümliwasser.)
result.name: Slivovitz

result.description: Juice made from sloe. In some countries, sloe cordial is available, and these two can substitute each other.
result.name: Sloe Juice

result.description: A must-have. Carbonated water, sparkling water, seltzer – soda water has a lot of names. Make your own by a siphon, or buy it by the bottle.
result.name: Soda Water

result.description: Ready-made sour mix is squeezed lime or lemon, simple syrup, and egg white (or superficial egg white). Make your own by shaking these ingredients.
result.name: Sour Mix

result.description: Sparkling white wine add a glamorous twist. Champagne is of course the king, but in cocktails and drinks other kinds is okay, too.
result.name: Sparkling Wine

result.description: A perfect non-alcoholic sparkle that is mostly used for adding a bit of glamour and adultness to virgin cocktails. Slightly sweeter than it´s alcoholic sibblings. The sparkle though, is the same.
result.name: Sparkly grape

result.description: As the name reveals, spiced rum gets its flavor from spices – often in secret constitutions.
result.name: Spiced Rum

result.description: Syrup with bite – here the simple syrup is mixed with chile pepper and herbs. Can be substituted by muddling chile pepper in simple syrup to taste.
result.name: Spicy Syrup

result.description: Very regular in Chinese cuisine, the star anise is also common for flavoring spirits. In pastis drinks, star anise make perfect garnish.
result.name: Star Anise

result.description: Here's a full meal: Stout beer is richer, sweeter, and darker than any other beer. There are sweet stouts and bitter stouts, both occur in beer drinks.
result.name: Stout Beer

result.description: A fortified red wine that has been flavored with quinine. There are a few substitutes to this unusual mixer.
result.name: St. Raphael

result.description: A drinking straw is a tubed piece of plastic used for sucking up drinks, and comes in different lengths. looks nice in pairs, but in our humble opinions, straws and a swizzle stick cannot co-exist in the same drink; it's either or.
result.name: Straw

result.description: One of the most beloved berries is also known for its aphrodisiac qualities. You will need to take the green caps off before muddling, but for garnish you can just rinse them. If you want a drink to taste like summer, use strawberries: it’s hard to go wrong.
result.name: Strawberry

result.description:
20 ripe fresh strawberries (washed, hulled and halved)
1 cup caster sugar
1 tablespoon crushed black peppercorns
½ cup water
Let all ingredients simmer in a pan for 15 minutes, cool off and sieve into a bottle. Keeps for up to two weeks in the fridge.
result.name: Strawberry and Black Peppercorn Syrup

result.description: Although strawberries are common in big parts of the world, the juice of it is not that common in the store next door. If you don't find it, you can do your own with a food processor, some sugar, and a colander.
result.name: Strawberry Juice

result.description: Regarding how beloved the strawberry is, the liqueur should be extremely popular around the world. It is a rather useful mixer, but not top five liqueurs, rather around
result.name: Strawberry Liqueur

result.description: If you don't find strawberry puree in your store, it's rather easy to do at home. Place fresh or frozen, cleaned, strawberries in a blender or mixer with a couple of dashes of lemon juice and one or two pinches of sugar. Run your processor until the puree is smooth and flat. Will keep fresh in the fridge for a week, if properly sealed.
result.name: Strawberry Puree

result.description: Traditionally maybe more of a breakfast supplement, this syrup might just come in handy in the bar as well.
result.name: Strawberry Syrup

result.description: An Italian liqueur, made from herbs and flowers. Hard to replace.
result.name: Strega

result.description: In rare cases, drink recipes call for cubed sugar instead of simple syrup, as the cubed form of sugar has effects of suction.
result.name: Sugar Cube (brown)

result.description: In rare cases, drink recipes call for cubed sugar instead of simple syrup, as the cubed form of sugar has effects of suction.
result.name: Sugar Cube (white)

result.description: Most often, when sugar is used in the bar, we use simple syrup. However, sometimes superfine sugar can be used as well. If unavailable, syrup is okay too.
result.name: Sugar, Superfine

result.description: A sweet and arrack tasting, rum-based liquor from Sweden. Often served as avec with coffee in its home country.
result.name: Swedish Punsch

result.description: Just after prohibition ended in the US, the swizzle stick was invented in 1933. Today, its used for long drinks in bars all over the world. A must-have in all bars.
result.name: Swizzle Stick

result.description: Like simple syrup, it is a sugar and water mixture, but has an added ingredient of gum arabic which prevents the sugar from crystallizing and adds a smooth texture.
result.name: Syrup de Gomme

result.description: Originally an African fruit, now grown in Asia and South America as well. More common in cooking than in the bar.
result.name: Tamarind Juice

result.description:
The Tangerine (Citrus reticulata) is an orange or red colored citrus fruit, a type of Egyptian orange.
They are smaller than most oranges, and the skin of some varieties peels off more easily. The taste is often more sour, or tart, than that of an orange.
result.name: Tangerine

result.description: Orange-like, small citrus fruit tangerine should have a liqueur? Of course it should! Question is if you need one – it's reasonably substituted with triple sec.
result.name: Tangerine Liqueur

result.description: Port wine with tawny color, hence the name. Can be replaced with regular port wine.
result.name: Tawny Port

result.description: Coffee drinks are popular, tea dittos are on the raise. Try and use strong flavored tea for best result.
result.name: Tea

result.description: Coffee drinks are popular, tea dittos are on the raise. Try and use strong flavored tea for best result.
result.name: Tea (hot)

result.description: Spirits made in the Tequila region in Mexico. It is made from the agave plant, and comes aged (añejo) as gold tequila, or "white" – regular.
result.name: Tequila Blanco

result.description: Bar-wise, the tomato is normally represented in juice form. Sometimes, the very vegetable is used too – try a cocktail tomato as garnish for your Bloody Mary.
result.name: Tomato

result.description: The quality of a bar is by many experts measured by their Bloody Maries. Keep fresh tomato juice (preferably on small cans) in your bar to keep on top of things.
result.name: Tomato Juice

result.description: This bitter, carbonated mixer is probably one of the most known there is. Due to the quinine in it, tonic water will glow in ultra violet light. You probably must have tonic in your bar, if any classic bar customer is expected.
result.name: Tonic Water

result.description: Triple Sec is an orange flavored liqueur used cocktails like the Cosmopolitan, Margaritas and Long Island Ice tea and many other delicious cocktails. Meaning, "triple distilled," triple sec is made from the dried peels of bitter and sweet oranges. Triple sec can be served neat, on the rocks or as mixer for a variety of cocktails. If you are to buy just one liqueur, you might want it to be triple sec as it's extremely useful in the bar.
result.name: Triple Sec

result.description: Whenever vanilla is involved in a drink, the pod or bean can make a nice garnish. Go easy if muddling, though, as it might give too much flavor.
result.name: Vanilla

result.description: Ice cream is great when you want to make milkshakes for grown-ups. Or if you just feel like having... Ice cream.
result.name: Vanilla Ice Cream

result.description: A nice liqueur with a great taste. (If you don't go for ABSOLUT VANILIA, which in a way makes the vanilla liqueur obsolete.) Can also be substituted with vanilla syrup.
result.name: Vanilla Liqueur

result.description: A rum-based liqueur with vanilla flavor.
result.name: Vanilla Rum

result.description: Syrup with vanilla taste is huge in coffee, and comes in handy in the bar, too.
result.name: Vanilla Syrup

result.description: Also known as bianco, sweet white vermouth is often served as apéritif.
result.name: Vermouth, Sweet

result.description: Also known under the French name, crème de violette, this is a collective label for liqueurs tasting from violet. Hard to replace (not hard to find drinks without it.)
result.name: Violet Liqueur

result.description: Also known as Japanese horseradish. Extremely unusual in the bar so far – the future might hold further grandness for the wasabi paste.
result.name: Wasabi Paste

result.description: Do you drink your tap-water? If yes: Use it in drinks too. If not: Use bottled water.
result.name: Water

result.description: Watermelon juice is a mouth watering summery juice. Perfect for the drinks you want to sip in the afternoon on the terrace.
result.name: Watermelon Juice

result.description: Pink and full of flavour, Watermelon Liqueur gives a fresh and sweet taste to your cocktail and brings summer into your glass.
result.name: Watermelon Liqueur

result.description: A nice liqueur, based on Scotch whisky. Often used in whiskey drinks, and hard to replace.
result.name: Whisky/Honey Liqueur

result.description: When called for in drink recipes, cacao liqueur is the "normal" one. A good friend to have in the bar, especially for cocktails.
result.name: White Cacao Liqueur

result.description: A very sweet mixer, the white chocolate liqueur. Thick and white in color, as opposed to the clear cacao liqueur. You can probably get quite far with the latter and without the first.
result.name: White Chocolate Liqueur

result.description: The recent dark chocolate craze has also raised interest for its white relative, not the lest among bartenders across the globe. The white chocolate stick makes a great garnish.
result.name: White Chocolate Stick

result.description: White chocolate is made of cocoa butter, milk, and sugar – no actual cocoa solids makes it lack the brown color. As syrup, white chocolate is extremely sweet: be careful!
result.name: White Chocolate Syrup

result.description: White cranberry juice isn't white at all: It's clear. Slightly milder than the red, regular version, this mixer took the world by storm by the turn of the millennia. Can be replaced with cranberry juice.
result.name: White Cranberry Juice

result.description: Most of the white grapes in the world end up the same way: being turned into wine. But the juice has qualities that easily can come in handy in the bar: a sweet, pure and mature taste to mix with spirits of you choice.
result.name: White Grape Juice

result.description: This nut takes some cracking to get hold of. White peach puree might be sold in big supermarkets, otherwise try making it by mixing white-fleshed, peeled and stoned peaches with a bit of sugar and a dash of lemon to taste.
result.name: White Peach Puree

result.description: Classic beverage made of green grapes. When used in cocktails, usually it's best to use a dry white wine.
result.name: White Wine

result.description: Considered the best among pear liqueurs, this is a nice mixer to keep in the bar. Not super important, though.
result.name: Williams Pear Liqueur

result.description: Woodruff is a very rare ingredient in cocktails, but it is on the rise so why not give it a try? The taste is herbal and fresh and leads your imagination to vanilla and fresh cut grass.
result.name: Woodruff Syrup

result.description: A peculiar mixer with roots in the 19th century of India. Best known for its participation in the Bloody Mary recipe.
result.name: Worcestershire Sauce

result.description: A milder version of Green Chartreuse, both being made in Voiron, France. But the herbal mixture that the spirits are based upon, are made and known by three monks only. Mysterious!
result.name: Yellow Chartreuse

result.description: A fresh mixer, for summer parties with a blender at hand. Can probably be replaced with whole milk.
result.name: Yoghurt
